questions.question: After performing the V-notch experiment, what is the most likely reason the actual discharge is less than the theoretical discharge?

answers.c: Energy losses due to friction and turbulence

explanations.a: Incorrect – notch width affects flow but doesn't explain lower discharge directly.
explanations.b: Incorrect – temperature has a minor effect under standard conditions.
explanations.c: Correct – real fluid losses reduce actual discharge. Learn more
explanations.d: Incorrect – it affects time, not discharge directly.

questions.question: Which measurement most directly impacts the accuracy of the calculated discharge in a V-notch experiment?

explanations.a: Incorrect – time matters for volume collection but not as critical as head.
explanations.c: Correct – small errors in H cause large errors in Q since Q ∝ H^5/2. Reference

questions.question: What is typically plotted to verify the discharge relationship in the V-notch experiment?

explanations.a: Incorrect – this is for orifice-type flow.
explanations.b: Incorrect – not used to verify discharge relationship.
explanations.c: Acceptable, but not linear for V-notch verification.
explanations.d: Correct – Q ∝ H^(5/2) in V-notch theory. Reference

questions.question: How is the coefficient of discharge (Cd) determined experimentally in this setup?

answers.a: By measuring pressure at the notch
answers.b: By comparing actual and theoretical discharge

explanations.a: Incorrect – pressure is not directly used.
explanations.c: Part of theory, but not enough alone.

questions.question: If a graph of Q vs H^2.5 is a straight line, what does it indicate?

answers.c: The experimental data follows theoretical prediction

explanations.b: Incorrect – the formula is validated by the straight line.
explanations.c: Correct – linearity confirms Q ∝ H^2.5 relationship.
explanations.d: Incorrect – unsteady flow would create a scatter plot.
